story_txt:
The big goal:                    $200,000We've already raised:     $63,400 Our current goal:            $136,600* Middle School: Three classrooms and a library.* Clinic: Waiting room & exam room, staffed by a private doctor once a week.* Short term mission house: Giving teams from all over the world a hands-on opportunity to serve in Guatemala.* Staff mission home: An apartment style home above the clinic & team house so our family can finally live in the village we serve.______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________My boys were starving...As I was teaching my 5th graders about the importance of GROWING our belief in Christ by reading our Bible and praying, I asked them, "Who goes to church every week?"  I don't know what I was expecting but of the 20 boys in class that day, just 3 raised their hand.  The next day I asked the 6th graders the same question.  Again, just a few hands went up. THAT'S when I realized the boys were STARVING.  It's no wonder they were so interested in learning about the Bible!  The only place they were getting fed spiritually was at the academy which was just a few days a week.  My boys were starving, right in front of me and I didn't even know it.I felt like I was in a burning house with the flames closing in.  I was in the final months with my 6th grade boys.  Next year they would be on their own.  They have all prayed and committed their lives to Christ but...were they ready?  Could they feed themselves???  Had I taught them to search after Him outside of the classroom?In the most humble part of me I realized, I had not.  I had failed them.  And it was too late.I prayed about it and I questioned, "What could I have done differently?  What could I do about it NOW...in this moment?"That's where the idea for a Christian middle school was born.  What if...what if I had THREE MORE YEARS with the 6th graders?  WHAT IF I spent three years discipling them?  Teaching them to search after God...on their own?  What if I could teach them to share what they learned?This is the answer I received from the Holy Spirit, "You can.  It's not too late.  I am with you."Building this middle school will have an incredible impact on these boys.  It COMPLETELY changes the direction of their lives.  Yes, they will have the education they need to earn a better living but more importantly, at the end of middle school, they will have a firm foundation in Christ.    And yes, please pray for the crazy lady "doctor"(We met Florinda and Marcos early in our ministry when we were first learning about the state of medical care in the villages of Guatemala.  We wrote this post in 2013.)
This morning we visited Marcos, a 13 month old who has not been feeling well. He’s had a fever for 3 days and diarrhea for over a week. 
“Has he seen a doctor?” I asked his mom, Florinda.
“I’m going to see her today. I’m leaving this morning.”
I was relieved. I wasn’t comfortable with those types of symptoms and if it were my son, we would be visiting a doctor.
“Can we pray for you and Marcos?”
She nodded yes. She seemed so distracted.
As we were praying, I felt the Holy Spirit of God telling me to drive her to the doctor. 
“What time is your appointment?” I asked.
“I don’t have an appointment,” she answered.
“Can we drive you?”
“Yes. Thank you,” she said with a shy smile.
We parked the van and walked down an alley. We passed a parked truck with 5 young men, and an older woman standing around it. The scene seemed sketchy to me. We asked if they know where the Dr.’s office was. The older lady walked up to us and told us that she died yesterday! My mind was racing!  What? 
“I’m just kidding! I’m the doctor!”
We should have just walked away. 
We entered a metal door of what looked like a home, not a doctor’s office. There was a handmade sign outside the door, “Firewood for sale”. As we walked through the narrow hall, there were piles of 2nd hand clothes and another sign, “Clothes for sale”. At the end of the hallway, there were eight chicken crates with live chickens. She seemed to trust this “doctor”, so we kept going. She parted a curtain that led to…her bedroom! I’m not kidding! A bed, a dresser, small refrigerator, mirror, family photos! 
 We should have walked away. 
“Lay your baby on the bed. Tell me, how is your baby feeling?”
After listening to the symptoms and poking around his tummy, she said she had something for Marcos and that she would be right back.  She came back with a small glass of watery oatmeal looking “stuff”. 
At this point I really felt like I might be in shock because I couldn’t seem to speak fast enough. In my best Spanish I tried to understand what she was asking Florinda to give Marcos. He’s trying to swallow but can’t seem to drink it fast enough as this crazy lady is prodding Florinda to force it down. I can confidently say, this lady was NOT a doctor, and we needed to get out of there. 
“How much do we owe you?” I asked.
“20 Quetzales.” Which is the equivalent of $2.50. We overpaid. 
We left the bedroom, walked passed the chickens and clothes and firewood. We walked back down the creepy alley to my van.
“Florinda, can I take you to the doctor I take my kids to?”
She nodded yes. 
We drove 40 minutes and met with a real doctor. When we explained what we had just gone through, he said it's very common and a big problem in Guatemala. Because the smaller villages don’t have a doctor, someone eventually starts mixing home remedies. Unfortunately, every village has a crazy lady “doctor” who knows nothing about medicine.
After examining Marcos and talking with his mom, the doctor explained that the baby has an infection and needs treated right away. BUT, the bigger problem is that Marcos is severely malnourished. He looks like a 5 month old and can’t sit up, let alone crawl or walk. The doctor can’t even prescribe antibiotics because he feels they need to be administered by an IV and watched closely by a physician.
This news is devastating to Florinda. She doesn’t want to go back to the hospital. She was just there with Marcos for a month, and now the doctor is saying Marcos may need 4 more months of hospitalization to get him healthy again.
All I can see is the fear in her eyes.
And here is the root of the problem. As we walked out of the doctor’s office, I paid 150 Quetzales, which is the equivalent of $20 U.S. You and I know that’s an inexpensive doctor visit, but that’s a mountain of money to people of the villages. 
The drive home was quiet. I can’t imagine what she was thinking. I encouraged her and let her know that we would help in any way we could. We would pray for her and visit her. We parked the van and walked her to her home. “If the doctor says we have to take him in, we have to do it,” she said.
I always imagined that as a missionary, my days would end with feelings of satisfaction or at least contentment. But our drive home was a lot like it is on most days, driving quietly, with my heart breaking into a million pieces. 
Please pray that Marcos gets to the hospital this week. Please pray for a full recovery to a healthy weight. Please pray that his parents would have patience and strength. And yes, please pray for the crazy lady “doctor”.
That was 3 years ago!  Florinda took Marcos to the National Hospital and after a few days returned home.  We visited Marcos and delivered PediaSure every week for 6 months.  We prayed and stood by their family as Marcos gained weight and began to grow!  I recently saw Florinda and Marcos walking in the village.  I took this picture and plan to hang it in the clinic as a reminder of God's faithfulness.  This is why we’re determined to build a clinic.  We want to give moms an alternative to back alley medicine.  Along with a private Guatemalan doctor, we'll have a team of nurses who will visit from the States every month to help moms like Florinda.  They’re committed to teaching about the importance of clean water and clean air stoves.  They’re committed to loving a village that, for the most part, has been forgotten. 
The Power of Prayer Journal
After 4 years in Guatemala, this is what I've learned. You cannot be impactful as a missionary without God.  It seems obvious but it's not.  AND, we need to draw closer to Him daily through prayer and Bible study.  THOSE are the building blocks of being a missionary.  And those are the building blocks of this journal.

Vonda and I wanted a more organized way to share our thoughts and prayers with God.  Even as missionaries, it can be hard to stay focused on the most important things.  And for us, spending time with God, LOVING God, is THE MOST IMPORTANT thing. We dreamed about, designed and printed this journal right here in Guatemala, on the mission field. We LOVE IT, and we want YOU to have it!When you donate $50 or $100 or even $1,000 toward this project, we want to give you The Power of Prayer Journal.  It’s our gift to you.  It's had SO MUCH IMPACT on our prayer life, we want EVERYONE to have one."I love my journal! It's a great way to be intentional about my time with God. I love sitting down before bed and recapping my day and acknowledging who God put in my path. Keeping a prayer list has also allowed me to recognize answered prayers and to give God the praise for how He is on the move! I will not go a day without it!"  - JackieEven if you can't donate to this project, you can still get the journal.  Just share this campaign and GET A PDF of The Power of Prayer Journal!

____________________________________________________________

____________________________________________________________

YOU MADE IT TO THE END!  First of all, THAT'S AMAZING!  Now, I need you to do two things.1. Scroll up and check out the "Perks" on the right.  Pray about how you can support this campaign.  You can also click "BACK IT" near the top where you can donate any amount you want.  2. Send me an email to let me know you made it to the end.  Everyone who emails me at georgesisneros@gmail.com will be entered to win the BEAUTIFUL, flowered handbag in the photo below.  I'll also stuff it with 10lbs of Guatemalan coffee!  WHAT???  Yea.  I know.  It's valued at $150!  Shhhhh.  Almost no one will have read this far so you have a pretty good chance of winning!  Winner will be announced on January 1st 2017.  ANYONE CAN WIN.  Only immediate family members are disqualified.  Yes, even if you're Taylor Swift or Lisa Bevere, YOU CAN WIN!  "I always begin my day with two prayers.  Lord, would You put the people in my path that You want me to love today?  And for just a moment, just a few seconds, would You allow me to see them through Your eyes?  With true love?"  George Sisneros, Missionary

story:
Black History is MORE than slavery, colonization, and the struggle for basic human rights.

 

Starting from a young age, students deserve the opportunity to learn about their heritage. Unfortunately, many Black/African-American students are made to believe their history only spans over the past 300 hundred years; and that this history can be covered accurately and thoroughly all within the month of February.

 

History plays a crucial role in how we identify ourselves. It is vital to understand where we come from and how we move forward.

 

At Udeesa Systemics & Technology we have created educational tools to support the sustaining of an understanding of history and heritage. We utilize primary resources & storytelling to showcase the real Africa and encourage students to build curiosity and critical thinking skills. 


Udeesa is on the verge of releasing the latest edition of our interactive storybook series along with an iOS/Android Mobile Application, and we need your support to make these resources available to students and educators.

By combining traditional African folktales with technologies like virtual tourism, augmented reality, and virtual reality, students can visualize concepts and study cultures in new and interactive ways.  

 

 

Augmented Reality (AR) is the premier feature in the release of Volume 2 of our series. AR is an interactive experience of a real-world environment where the objects that reside in the real world are enhanced by computer-generated perceptual information, sometimes across multiple sensory modalities, including (but not limited to) visual, auditory, and haptic feedback.

 

 

Today, we are raising $20k to complete and distribute Volume 2 of our interactive African folklore series, accompanied by our first mobile application, Compass.


Compass will bring the stories of Anansi the Spider to life in the hands of our readers. Your contributions will allow us to further incorporate Augmented Reality, audio-visual playback & a directional compass into unique learning experiences with African History and folklore.

 

 

Udeesa’s Extended Reality (XR) Storybook Series combines these traditional West African Folktales with new and emerging immersive technologies.

 

 

The stories of 'Anansi the Spider' are originally Ghanaian folktales, now prevalent throughout the world, where Anansi the Spider is considered to be the keeper of all knowledge & stories. Anansi and his countless adventures reflect lessons and proverbs that have sustained communities throughout African history. 

Given persistent racial inequities in education and the nature of curricula still dense in Eurocentric perspectives, there is a lack of inclusion felt by many Black/African descendant students. Because of this discrepancy, there is an urgency to embrace new & equitable teaching techniques in the classroom that are compatible with both virtual & in-person learning. 

 

 

The history of Africa has deeply affected development throughout the world. But there is a glaring failure in traditional education contributing to the ignorance, inaccurate representation, and mistrust among individuals from different backgrounds. As witnessed throughout American history, and particularly last year, 2020, the pains caused by this failure are felt especially by people of Black, and African descent.

The technology and resources offered by Udeesa are designed to support traditional education: through the use of sustainable hands-on learning solutions. With your help, we will empower students and educators by demonstrating the impact of our AR interactive storybook series. 

 

 

Africa and Afro-descendant Histories and Cultures are some of the richest found throughout the world…

... including, but not limited to symbols & philosophies such as the Adinkra, dynasties like the Songhai, Nubia, Zulu, personalities/people like Mansa Musa, Anansi, Imhotep/Ramsey, and the foundations of Egyptian gods.

 

Despite African history directly impacting international trade, culture, and customs; The impact and implications of growth on the African continent are rarely explored outside of the topics of enslavement of African peoples and colonization.

 

Udeesa Systemics & Technology is a product of the frustrations caused by this lack of exploration, and a dedication to changing these outdated stereotypes & narratives. 

 

Founded by Asante Asiedu [Middle] during his time at Lehigh University, Udeesa is an educational technology company changing the way African and Afro-descendant history and culture are taught and learned about. 

Our founder, alongside countless students from diverse backgrounds, experienced the severe misrepresentation and weak academic engagement provided around African heritage and culture in schools.

"Udeesa presents a unique opportunity to apply technology towards understanding, evaluating & implementing impact-driven learning solutions.

In support of students’ mental health and the evolving public interest in African heritage and culture, I hope that whether a direct descendant of the African continent or not, the use of our learning tools & strategies will promote deeper thought towards the growth of equitable educational practices."

- Asante Asiedu

 

Taking African history & folklore to the next level!

 

Folktales are an amazing resource that can help students begin to learn about other cultures from an early age. They also develop strong reading and comprehension skills, model positive character traits, and discover a love of stories and for curious learning.

 

 

By adding new technologies to each storybook in our series: teachers and students are able to develop their technical literacy while also learning in new and engaging ways.

 

Books are no longer confined to just the physical pages. Students can to take virtual tours of real locations mentioned in their stories, see their favorite characters come to life, and witness tradition taking place before their very eyes. 

 

 

We asked students, ranging in age & ethnicity, what their experiences learning about Black history, Africa, and Afro-descendant culture had been and in almost every case the answer was the same... 

...Slavery, Colonization, & the pursuit of Civil Rights.

 

...What was your learning experience?

 

As the global population continues to increase, the study of African history and culture will only grow in relevance. Students want to understand their neighbors, communities, and themselves as they further their global interests.

While the Trans-Atlantic slave trade jumpstarted the industrial revolution in the United States, the labor of enslaved Africans and the livelihoods of their descendants have laid the foundations of countless nations in every continent. 

The intersections of African history and culture remain at the forefront of our everyday lives; Using emerging technologies to explore Black and African history will not only provide us with a deeper understanding of world history but will also...

  • Increase confidence surrounding culture & identity
  • Generate higher engagement among students of color 
  • Combat ignorance and racial prejudice 
  • Create new & rich learning environments
  • Provide a deeper breadth of knowledge about cultures (as a result of early exposure) 
  • And foster transformative learning opportunities

 

 

Risks & Challenges

While we understand that the depths of Black & African history cannot be fully grasped by any one individual or organization alone, our goal through this campaign is to provide a first of its kind experience with technology and information surrounding Africa starting with the most traditional form of education: Storytelling. 

Regardless of whether Black Americans or members of the diaspora identify as Africans or not, any population of people should have a basic understanding of their history and where their ancestry lies.

Though most white Americans no longer identify as European, we are taught European history. We learn about European kings, wars, art, and literature. However in comparison, by the time most students have completed their standard education, they have only learned one aspect of the history of this segment of our population (slavery, colonization, and civil rights.) 

Unfortunately, these same teachings present Black history in a far less flattering light. Beginning with colonization and slavery and ending with the present state of civil rights. It is a surprise to most when they learn that there are thousands of years of history in Africa rich with kingdoms, rulers, systems of commerce, governance, trade, art, and scientific advances. 

A dismissive educational system combined with false narratives presented by lingering stereotypes and social media are our biggest hurdles. Misinformation has left many people seeing Africa as strictly a place of poverty and suffering.

But this is far from the truth, and through our campaign, Udeesa will continue to build the tools necessary to look past these misleading ideas and narrow-minded perspectives to forge a new path.

Our combination of modern technologies to traditional folktales will allow us to begin to reintroduce African philosophies, aphorisms, and proverbs to learners of all ages and they will gain exposure to the African continent in ways that they have never had before. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

You can support our cause by spreading the word about our campaign and encouraging others to join the conversation about changing the way Africa is taught and learned about.

Contact us at community@udeesa.org for inquiries, ideas or more information about engaging with our solutions.

story:
2 Card Decks to play any classic and innovative card game, powered by an Augmented Reality app that shows material related to each specific event and personality.

 


Instead of lifting a 1000+ page book on American history, hold multiple decades in one tiny package.

 

 

Incredible stories, unforgettable moments, emotions that are (literally) yet to come…

story:
50 members. 4 competitions. 3 robots. 1 team. The Falcons.

The deafening roar of cheers rattles Dorton Arena as one name is called to receive the Rookie All-Star Award. Green Hope Robotics. 50 teams, 15 rookies, and we were the team that won.  This win opened the door to internationals where we had a chance to compete at the global competition of robotics.


Who are we?

The Falcons are a family from Green Hope High School bound by a passion for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM).  There are seniors to freshman, boys and girls, and people who have roots from all around the world.  We strive to have a 50/50 balance of boys and girls on our team to promote the women’s role in STEM education and career fields. This diversity teaches the team to accept and admire the differences of those around us and how to work with various types of people.


We share STEM with the community.

  1. We signed a document with the Town of Cary making September STEM month.



  2. We designed a prosthetic attachment for wounded veterans and won the grand prize.


  3. We collected 250 computers, that were then recycled and given to underprivileged kids.


  4. We started a LEGO Robotics team (FLL) for a local middle school.


  5. We coordinated various outreach events at schools and within our community.


We are an active group and are willing to put more energy into developing humanity through education and hard work.  That is why we need your help.

STEM and The Future

We found some universal truths.  Our young people are the future.  STEM helps create a brighter future.  With collaboration and hard work anything is possible.  Put simply, our students are given a challenge and expected to create physical solution through STEM application.  Anyone with experience programming, CAD designing using software, physically manipulating materials, and/or running a large team already knows those can be challenging enough.  These are high school students, they have tests and homework, jobs, etc. and yet they still find 10-20 hours a week to develop STEM skills.  Their works ripple effect goes further than their own personal lives.  


Please help us reduce the time we spend on fundraising so we can invest more time in STEM principles and their application.

We started a LEGO Robotics team (FLL) for a local middle school.




We coordinated various outreach events at schools and within our community.




We are an active group and are willing to put more energy into developing humanity through education and hard work.  That is why we need your help.STEM and The FutureWe found some universal truths.  Our young people are the future.  STEM helps create a brighter future.  With collaboration and hard work anything is possible.  Put simply, our students are given a challenge and expected to create physical solution through STEM application.  Anyone with experience programming, CAD designing using software, physically manipulating materials, and/or running a large team already knows those can be challenging enough.  These are high school students, they have tests and homework, jobs, etc. and yet they still find 10-20 hours a week to develop STEM skills.  Their works ripple effect goes further than their own personal lives.  Please help us reduce the time we spend on fundraising so we can invest more time in STEM principles and their application.

story:
Hi, this is Corlens, a state-of-the-art collaboration software that help shapes the future of education, schooling and business! We also revolutionize how people collaborate in distant places. The platform simplifies effective time management and balances heavy workload, by providing a comprehensive set of tools to ease your mind and satisfy your needs. Corlens Premier is loaded with a wide array of functions; you can make the most of it - from group web browsing, application sharing, to collaborative workspace, and presentation viewer.

Our software benefits everyone, from education, small teams and charities, to large corporations in different industry sectors. We believe that the society are currently adapting to more technologically-oriented means, and by utilizing our modern server technologies, robust communications systems and portable devices, we make long distance collaboration a breeze! Take lead in communication over the next century today!

This is a draft design of the software, hopefully help you get a better insight of what our future product might look like. Please note that the elements in this illustration are subject to change.


Education is a crucial aspect of life, it empowers people to sustain the world in different ways, and get the most value out of life. However, our approach to schooling are radically changing, and by equipping online schools with the tools they need to make this happen, we help embrace the future of education! We help talented students pursue their interests, and continue their education even when they’re abroad – CLICK, LAUNCH, AND GO!

On top of that, our distraction-free virtual classroom aids effective learning, with features such as timer, groups, whiteboard tools, alerts, and teachers' controls.


A unified cross platform conferencing solution that empowers businesses to launch a meeting or staff training sessions, anytime, anywhere. Our platform reinvents teleconferencing, and simplifies their approach to effective management and communication. During the meeting, the administration team can share documents, activate HD video or voice chat, and even launch a presentation on the go! From small businesses to transnational corporations, our platform will benefit them greatly. For instance, we help them reduce travel costs and make decisions faster than ever.


International charities often faces many challenges, the most common ones are dispersed attention. With so many remote offices and home volunteers across the globe, communication and information sharing can be laborious. While such issues are easily addressed with our conferencing platform! Our platform reduces the complexity and costs, even a non-techie could arrange a meeting, share documents, and brainstorm ideas for their next move.

Certain types of charity will be eligible for a massive discount, while other charities, such as for-profit ones, are not eligible for discounts. We might consider giving away exclusive software licenses in the future; applies to non-profit charities only.

* The actual release dates may be earlier than expected.

Grab a perk, get rewarded, and support us - all at once! You can check them out, and choose the one that suits you! Please note that these perks will be fulfilled upon the official release of our software, and will be delivered to your email. Once our website are fully operational, you can use the promotional code given to you by email, and directly retrieve your copy of licence, depending on what perks you bought!


1. What is the current progress of this project?

This project is still at its inception, despite that system complexes, sketches are already at hand. In addition, media servers are being built, we are still in search of more team members for client app development and UI designer - they will be recruited shortly.

2. When will Corlens hit its general availability phase?

According to our plan, the software should be finished next year, probably November or so. While we set this goal for next year, there is no assurance, unforeseen setbacks may take place, especially when it comes to software development, but we will endeavour to get it done before the deadline.

3. What type of platforms or devices will this software support?

Our targets are on PCs, Macs and Android mobile phones. We believe accessibility and compatibility is very important. We will, therefore start with Windows platform, then slowly move onto the Android platform, and afterwards, Mac OS X.

4. Why are iPads and iPhones unsupported, and when are they going to be supported?

Now you might ask yourself when will iPad and iPhone be supported, and why we did not make it a high priority? Well, since our software will be cross-platform, we will need to ensure that its compatible with every OS and/or its distributions. However, porting our entire code base to iOS will require complete UI redesign, and will cause server incompatibility as well. Therefore, we will settle with Windows, and Linux distributions first (including Android), and afterwards, we will attempt to address this issue, and develop its software accordingly.

5. How will the funds be used?

Our foremost goal is to recruit more team members to make this idea a reality; we've got the means to do it! We are also in search of programmers, server maintenance crew, as well as more graphic and UI designers. We aim at recruiting a team of different nationalities; combine their experiences, thoughts, and ideas to perfect our software to its maximum potential. On top of that, some funds will be used to rent additional server racks, sustaining more concurrent users. A complete team will allow us to build a better software for the masses.

6. What about overhead, how will the extra funds be used?

Assuming that if the extra funds reaches $20,000, we'll use it to rent more robust servers and distribute its workload more evenly, to ensure maximum speed and reliability. What if more? Since system security and hijacking are also some of our major concerns... therefore, if the overhead reaches another $100,000, we will attempt to reinforce our security by developing end-to-end encryption algorithms.

7. Can I get a money back?

Absolutely. Customer satisfaction has been our ethos since the very beginning. There's two ways to do it, the first method is to simply contact Indiegogo for your money back. The second way is to contact us directly; whichever way you choose are all fine by us. For more information, please visit HERE.




That's all there is to this project! Thanks for glancing over our project, we hope you'll like it, and be willing to help! You can also like, share, or follow us on our social networks, and be sure to spread our word! Go on, you know you want to! Thanks again!

story:
https://www.facebook.com/tomorrowatschool/

Who we are


Tomorrow at School Association (TASA) is a local organization based in Phnom Penh, which will open the first child-care center in December. We work with the urban poor, supporting them in escaping from poverty. We believe that education changes not only their personal lives but also their society and their country. We carefully listen to each person in the community and are patient in building their capacity and encouraging their development. This is what makes us different.

Our primary focus is children living in urban poor settlements of Phnom Penh. Children are often the most vulnerable. They have been discriminated against and ignored by society. Due to the situation of hopelessness the adults find themselves in, they often engage in drugs, drinking, and gambling which results in family violence, and the children become victimized.

TASA works to prevent the children from losing their belief in their future. We provide basic needs for children such as education and a proper diet for their age group based on international standards. At the same time we encourage the development of the capacity of their parents and the community in becoming more independent. Independency will allow them to solve problems by themselves, to improve their lives for the future. Our prime focus is to provide community development through supporting slum children, the future generation.

We want them to get free from poverty and to have choices in their decisions. We want children to have a dream for their future and have joy in their life. We want them to believe they are needed by their society.

Your support for Tomorrow at School Association can provide education for slum children, which will brighten their future and possibilities.


Why Cambodia?


While Phnom Penh’s economy has been growing rapidly over the past decade, the growing urban population, coupled with land insecurity, has been threatening to undermine stability for the disadvantaged. Those who are marginalised are not able to have a stable life, rather they are surviving hand-to-mouth. As a consequence, the weak are left to bear the burden; children. The difficulty of alleviating from poverty is believed to be due primarily to its particular history, which Cambodia traced.

The violent and destructive Khmer Rouge regime banned all traditional education activities. The Khmer Rouge closed down all the schools and teachers were outlawed; most of them didn’t survive the Khmer Rouge period.

The People’s Republic of Kampuchea which followed the fall of the Khmer Rouge faced an educational system which had to be recreated from almost nothing, there was a total lack of teachers, premises, books, and teaching equipment.

From an historical point of view, education in Cambodia is characterised by a sequence of disruptions. In comparison to the neighbouring countries Cambodia’s education system is still seen as being seriously handicapped by the recent history.

The historical tragedy, which destroyed the Cambodian education system, has still been casting a dark shadow on the education field in Cambodia.

In Anlong Kgnan slum, which is one of poorest areas in Phnom Penh, there are many infants, who are lacking in not only educational development but also in nutrition. As their parents are not aware of the importance of education, infants are often neglected. Infants are born much smaller than the world average and often times with birth defects and disabilites due to the maternal malnutrition of duration of the pregnancy and are growing up without enough nutrition.　Accordingly their physical strength is weak and their height is relatively small.












 

What we aim to do
 

There are two main reasons why school aged children do not go to school;

-their parents are not aware of the importance of education

-pupils themselves are not strong enough yet to follow the class due to being intellectually challenged.

Tomorrow At School Association aims at tackling both these issues, by establishing a child care center in the target community of Anlong Kgnan slum. We will rent a house in the slum, paving the surrounding areas and planting vegetables and fruits for their diet. We will supply all necessary materials for infants such as kitchen utilities, educational materials and some clothes, as they are often naked.


Our association will select 20 poorest infants from the slum and look after them from morning to evening, offering foods and education. Children will learn to improve their basic knowledge of mathematics, language training, and life skills. This will help enhance the quality of life of children and their parents.  We will also aim to establish that children can acquire proper nutrient intakes and dietary patterns. At the same time, parents will understand the importance of education for children aged 3-6 years old. These activities will increase the parent's support for children to access basic educational opportunities. Our activity will ultimately lead to community development. We expect all these children to get out of poverty when they get older, due to the opportunities we will provide them.

We will support children to believe that the world is good place to live and that they too deserve to live with dignity.


Where will my donation go?


We need an initial sum of $21,000 to get this first year of the project up and running.  This amount will provide a year of services for 20 children between 3-6 years old. It will directly impact 20 families or close to 100 people!

 

All funds raised will go toward the following:

Renting the space

Renovating the space and making it accessible

Paying salaries to teachers and assistants

Covering costs for lunch and snacks

Covering other on-going costs such as electricity, water etc.



Other ways you can help
 

Any contribution is welcome!

You can spread the word about the school and our campaign, by telling your friends and family and help us get the word out!  

We’re not looking only for financial help but any kind of material donation is welcome.
Visit our website to support us and also learn more about Tomorrow At School Association
www.tomorrowatschool.com

On behalf of the children in Cambodia:  Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Short Summary

Founded in 2000 on the belief that World Change Starts with Educated Children®, Room to Read’s innovative model focuses on deep, systemic transformation within schools in low-income countries during two time periods which are most critical in a child’s schooling: early primary school for literacy acquisition and secondary school for girls’ education. We work in collaboration with local communities, partner organizations and governments to develop literacy skills and a habit of reading among primary school children and ensure girls can complete secondary school with the skills necessary to negotiate key life decisions. Room to Read has benefited 10 million children across 17,000 communities in Asia and Africa and aims to reach 15 million children by 2020. Learn more at www.roomtoread.org.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are working within a marketing group at Baruch College in NYC. We are volunteering our time to help Room to Read impact children around the world.
  • We chose to work with Room to Read specifically because they have one of the lowest overhead costs amongst charity groups. So every dollar you send has a greater impact for these children around the world.
  • All of the money that we raise will be used for Room to Read's charity. Regardless of the outcome of this particular campaign we plan to help Room to Read as much as we can.

The Impact

  • Room to Read works in collaboration with local communities, partner organizations and governments to develop literacy skills and a habit of reading among primary school children and to ensure girls can complete secondary school with the skills necessary to negotiate key life decisions.
  • Room to Read has benefited 10 million children across 17,000 communities in Bangladesh, Cambodia, India, Laos, Nepal, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Tanzania, Vietnam and Zambia, and aims to reach 15 million children by 2020.

Transparency

It is important to know where your money is going. No one wants to see their money being used for purposes other than what was intended. Which is why we are proud to say that:

  • Room to Read has been recognized for its exceptional fiscal responsibility and financial health, and has been awarded the Charity Navigator 4-star rating for nine years in a row—a recognition that less than 1 percent of their rated charities can claim.
  • Room to Read pledges to continue to keep their overhead well below the industry average, to maximize the percentage of your contributions that go towards their programs, and to spend their program dollars wisely so that millions of children may benefit from their work.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you could share this important campaign with your friends and family that would be terrific (Social Media, email, and word of mouth).
  • Indiegogo has some great share tools to help pass along this campaign.
  • Also, If you cannot donate any money but still wish to help out. Room to Read accepts book donations through a partner site called www.betterworldbooks.com.
Thank you for all of your help. Nothing would be possible without your compassion.

story:
Short Summary

I'm Sean Womack, I'm in Year 11 (10th grade) at Cheney School in Oxford, UK. Recently, 20 other students and I were selected from ages 15-17 to go with Global Action (Their mission is to facilitate learning for positive global change through tailored school expeditions and professional internships) to the Indian Himalayas and do amazing charity work - as well as to learn a lot and have some fun. This trip will be in July 2017 for approximately 3 weeks.

I'm launching this campaign because this trip is VERY expensive. Since we are contributing so much to charity (approx 65% of the total due), this trip will cost £3000 (~$4300) per person. So I need to start getting funding ASAP.

When you contribute to this campaign, you are not only helping me get to India, but you are also helping the Tibetan communities that we will visit during the journey. If I get extra funding, that money will go to the other students in the group who are also trying to raise funds.


What I Need & What You Get

This whole trip costs about £50,000-£60,000 in all (that's for everyone - students, teachers and guides), so it's going to take a lot of work to get that money. I plan on getting a part-time job soon, but the first payment is due right away! The payments are spread out across many months, but the first one is right around the corner:

  1. £200 deposit (10th March 2016)
  2. £200 deposit (29th April 2016)
  3. £1000 (1st November 2016)
  4. £1600 (May 2017)
This total includes visa fees, travel, immunizations, accommodation, equipment, food, and personal needs. But the reason it's such a large fee is because this is a charity organization and most of the money goes to Global Action's sponsored charities. I will be contributing to my goal as well, by getting a part-time job. In addition, all of the students will be working together to raise about 10% of the funds as a group. 
When you donate, you will receive massive thanks from me, but also the knowledge that you've given to a worthy cause. I will be sure to thank every one of the contributors personally (see perks).

What will we be doing?

Day 1: We start in the UK and go through everything one final time to make sure we are all ready to go.

Day 2-3: We take an overnight flight from London to New Delhi and then a domestic flight to Amritsar. We'll find our hotel and relax for the night.

Day 4: We'll visit the Golden Temple, Maharajah's Palace, and the Guru-Ka-Langar. Later that afternoon, we'll travel to Dharamsala in the Himalayan foothills.

Day 5-6: We'll visit the Tibet Museum and Tsuglagkhang Temple as well as meet the 17th Gyalwang Karmapa and, if we're lucky, the Dalai Lama. There will be a Tibetan language lesson and seminars about the Tibetan government in exile. We'll learn about the physical geography of the Himalayan region. Finally, we will visit the Department of Education and the Tibetan Children's Village.

Day 7: We will learn about Fair Trade, and visit two companies: Dolls4Tibet and Blue Ulla.

Day 8-11: We will build a greenhouse, a school, and water pipes for the Tong-Len charity. We'll also spend time with Tibetan families.

Day 12-14: We'll go on a Himalayan trek through the foothills and camp out each night under the stars.

Day 15: We'll visit the Norbulingka Institute and learn how to make Indian food.

Day 16: We'll learn about Buddhism and learn how to meditate, and spend time at the Dolma Ling Nunnery.

Day 17: We embark on the journey back to New Delhi and spend time relaxing there.

Day 18: We visit the Taj Mahal!

Day 19: We fly back to the UK - forever changed for the better!

How can you help?

First of all, contribute! If you can't give to the campaign, then please let others know about it. I can use all the help I can get!

Thank you!
story_txt:
Short Summary
I'm Sean Womack, I'm in Year 11 (10th grade) at Cheney School in Oxford, UK. Recently, 20 other students and I were selected from ages 15-17 to go with Global Action (Their mission is to facilitate learning for positive global change through tailored school expeditions and professional internships) to the Indian Himalayas and do amazing charity work - as well as to learn a lot and have some fun. This trip will be in July 2017 for approximately 3 weeks.
I'm launching this campaign because this trip is VERY expensive. Since we are contributing so much to charity (approx 65% of the total due), this trip will cost £3000 (~$4300) per person. So I need to start getting funding ASAP.
When you contribute to this campaign, you are not only helping me get to India, but you are also helping the Tibetan communities that we will visit during the journey. If I get extra funding, that money will go to the other students in the group who are also trying to raise funds.


What I Need & What You Get This whole trip costs about £50,000-£60,000 in all (that's for everyone - students, teachers and guides), so it's going to take a lot of work to get that money. I plan on getting a part-time job soon, but the first payment is due right away! The payments are spread out across many months, but the first one is right around the corner: 
£200 deposit (10th March 2016)
£200 deposit (29th April 2016)
£1000 (1st November 2016)
£1600 (May 2017)
This total includes visa fees, travel, immunizations, accommodation, equipment, food, and personal needs. But the reason it's such a large fee is because this is a charity organization and most of the money goes to Global Action's sponsored charities. I will be contributing to my goal as well, by getting a part-time job. In addition, all of the students will be working together to raise about 10% of the funds as a group. When you donate, you will receive massive thanks from me, but also the knowledge that you've given to a worthy cause. I will be sure to thank every one of the contributors personally (see perks).  What will we be doing? Day 1: We start in the UK and go through everything one final time to make sure we are all ready to go.
Day 2-3: We take an overnight flight from London to New Delhi and then a domestic flight to Amritsar. We'll find our hotel and relax for the night.

Day 4: We'll visit the Golden Temple, Maharajah's Palace, and the Guru-Ka-Langar. Later that afternoon, we'll travel to Dharamsala in the Himalayan foothills.
Day 5-6: We'll visit the Tibet Museum and Tsuglagkhang Temple as well as meet the 17th Gyalwang Karmapa and, if we're lucky, the Dalai Lama. There will be a Tibetan language lesson and seminars about the Tibetan government in exile. We'll learn about the physical geography of the Himalayan region. Finally, we will visit the Department of Education and the Tibetan Children's Village.
Day 7: We will learn about Fair Trade, and visit two companies: Dolls4Tibet and Blue Ulla.
Day 8-11: We will build a greenhouse, a school, and water pipes for the Tong-Len charity. We'll also spend time with Tibetan families.
Day 12-14: We'll go on a Himalayan trek through the foothills and camp out each night under the stars.

Day 15: We'll visit the Norbulingka Institute and learn how to make Indian food.
Day 16: We'll learn about Buddhism and learn how to meditate, and spend time at the Dolma Ling Nunnery.
Day 17: We embark on the journey back to New Delhi and spend time relaxing there.
Day 18: We visit the Taj Mahal!
Day 19: We fly back to the UK - forever changed for the better!

    How can you help? First of all, contribute! If you can't give to the campaign, then please let others know about it. I can use all the help I can get!
Thank you!

story:
The Heart Story

As a Muslim growing up in America, I learned my faith through the traditional methods of watching my parents, relatives, family, and friends. I remember watching my mom helping people in a selfless way. I remember vividly witnessing my father's interaction with people with a warm and welcoming smile. However, as I didn't have that interaction, I  learned my faith by watching my parents. Having that connection with my mom and dad while learning my faith was missing.

So when I became a mother of two beautiful children, I wanted something different. I wanted to offer something for my children that will build a bond around my faith. Like any mom out there, I bought DVDs for my children to watch at home, or in the car. I also purchased many books about being a good Muslim, and to understand the basics of Islam. My children did learn, but buying books and DVDs still had the disconnect I once felt when I was a child. These ways of learning did not help me as a mom to interact in a fun hands-on way with my children.

That is the heart of how my venture began to start a company called Aspire Learning Tools,  that creates mindful games for spiritual kids. I wanted something engaging, fun, and interactive, while learning their faith! I wanted my children to experience making their own connection with Allah (God). I wanted them to understand their faith and how to practice their faith. 

The Project 

I began developing the Salah(Prayer) Matching Game around December 2015. I did so with one goal in mind, to bring more fun faith based games for Muslim families, Islamic schools, homeschoolers, and anyone who wants to learn more about who we are as Muslims and what Salah (Prayer) is in Islam. Since then a lot of work has been done to the game...both the physical box and visual design. Also, this two-year journey has lead to much traction in Arizona and all over the USA. I have worked with two schools in Arizona, created 20 prototypes that where sent out in the USA, and worked with local families. I have also created a Facebook Page to allow awesome folks like you to rate and write a review about the game. After hundreds of surveys and interviews from a speech therapist, Muslim, Non-Muslim educators, and families, the game is ready to go to the next level! 

Donate Today!

I have started this campaign because there is still more work that needs to be done. I have exhausted nearly all of my resources, and need this last push in order to complete the game. 

Your donation today will cover the cost of the following: 

  • Durable and more resistant cards. 
  • A more resistant and practical package.
  • New cool graphics for cards and package.
  • Start the production of the game! Woohoo!




The Impact

Educators: One of the difficulties as educators is finding games for classroom use that emphasize cultural diversity. Well…the Salah (prayer) Game is here to save the day! Take advantage of students' love to play games by spreading awareness; and open the students' eyes to the world around them! Whether you want to express interest in the religious background of your students or maintain a level of sensitivity to their faith, the Salah (Prayer) Game is the way to go!

Muslim Educators: For all the Muslim teachers out there, this is a great learning tool to seamlessly incorporate in existing curriculum that helps reinforce core values in the classroom, test child’s understanding of Salah (Prayer), and have fun while learning!

Parents & Families: Whether you want a glimpse of what a Muslim life entails; or need a way to incorporate your religion and faith, the Salah (Prayer) Matching Game is a perfect fun way to learn while creating lasting memories!

Revert: Along with the bold decision of conversion to the Islamic faith, is learning and understanding the language. That is why the Salah(prayer) game is a perfect gift for your family! This essential learning tool is a fun way to practice your new language, and get siblings to join you on your language adventure. This can keep new words and phrases fresh in your mind and build up your confidence for the next time you speak with someone, listen to lecture, or read related text.  


Testimonials 

Click on the link to find out more! #SalahMatchingGame

The survey shows this game totally changed their lives. This calls for more. So have a toast with me and join me on this mission! Please back this project and help me to help you.  We want to take The Salah Game to every corner of the world, making it an overall better place!


What You Get

Upon reaching my goal of $6,000, if you have donated towards the Testing Perks in this campaign, the game will be available in its first Beta Test phase by October 2016. Also, you will be the first to receive the limited edition Salah Game. Some of the perks offered here will NEVER be offered again, and will be given at the corresponding time. These perks do stack, so you can purchase three of the same perk for example. 

Risks & Challenges 
I need the funds to move forward with the project. I will persevere to launching the Beta Testing of the Salah Matching Game by August 2016, however, as always in production there may be unexpected delays and challenges that face the process and may cause delays, but we strive to keep production on target. 

Other Ways You Can Help :) 

Running low on the Benjamin...No worries! Here are simple ways you can make a difference:
  • Spread the word through your email contact list to friends and family!

  •  Make some noise about my campaign on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram! Use hashtag  #SalahMadeEasy #SalahMatchingGame
  • Word of mouth is powerful! Spread the word! TALK! TALK! and more TALK! 
  • Oh, one more thing...remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it. YOU ARE AWESOME!

Thank You!

Thank you for taking a look at my project, with your pledge today I can send this game to print--- and  next year I'll be back with even more mindful  games 4 spiritual kids!  Questions?  Comments?  Feedback?  I welcome it, after all I'm learning too.

story:
Even a €1 donation from you will make a huge difference to helping us! Please give what you can :)


Who we are.....

Hello, we are Peter Jordan and George O'Malley, and we are seeking election to Dail Eireann in Co.Mayo 

We are tired of experiencing bad representation and our county being neglected by our own man, Taoiseach Enda Kenny together with 3 other government TDs for the past 5 years. 

We believe that countless thousands others are also disillusioned. We know that if elected, even as independent TDs, we will have a far greater and more positive impact on Mayo's well being and it's future than Enda Kenny has had in his 40+ years as an elected TD, Minister and Taoiseach. 


Enda Kenny must go! 

We plan to unseat Enda Kenny and send a message to the entire country and to FF/FG/Lab that we will not tolerate the further planned neglect and abuse in County Mayo by those parties over the past 50+ years. Enda Kenny has been a TD for 41 years and has done nothing for the people of Mayo or the people of Ireland, only continually let us down domestically and internationally. 
His record really does speak for itself. Here is a man who sat by and watched Fianna Fail wreck our country and when given the opportunity to correct it, proved to be incapable of doing so, just a mere administrator for the troika and bondholders. If Ireland was a private company he would have got the chop 36 years ago.

It is time for a change. A change from - son of a TD  to national school teacher for 4 years, to TD. Let us not forget Enda's "Contract with the People". We need people with experience of life and business, with all of its ups and downs, experience of living beyond the walls of Dáil Éireann, but most of all we need elected officials who actually care about the people they represent. 

We can not let another generation of our greatest asset, our young, be forced to leave the country. This is not normal, it doesn't happen in other "1st world" countries. Mayo is often the county that comes off worst when we go through yet another bust in Ireland. Enda has been an elected TD through some of our most devastating economic depressions. 


Not just negative - We have plans too
We are not just looking to bash Enda Kenny and look for a protest vote. 

We have ideas, we have plans, we have experience and we have the unrelenting drive to make it happen. 

Mayo and the Western region in general have seen a chronic under investment or disinvestment in our key services and infrastructure. hospitals, roads, Knock airport, railway lines, IDA parks, rural Garda stations, doctors surgeries

We don't need to continue, if you have been to or live in Mayo you know all about it. 

Mayo doesn't look like a county with 4 TD's in power and it certainly doesn't look like a county that is home to the Taoiseach!


Below are some key objectives of George and Peter. We are ambitious, we do think big, its the least Mayo deserves after years of neglect.
 

• THE RETENTION OF OUR SERVICES

(schools, hospitals, clinics, garda stations)

• N5 NORTH FROM SWINFORD TO BELMULLET

• A KNOCK FREE ZONE

similar to Shannon's

• A RING ROAD FOR BALLINA

• 10km RURAL RENEWAL TAX INCENTIVE AREA

with Knock airport as the epicentre

• THE WESTERN RAIL LINK

• THE UPGRADE OF THE R312

from Castlebar to Bellacorick

• A MAYO DEEP SEA PORT 


We will never apologise for fighting for what Mayo deserves. This is our county and if we do not take a stand now, there will be no one left here to fight for.

What we need from you.....

We need money, there is no easy way around it. We are not a big organisation with €1,000,000s at our disposal. We are supported by a loyal following of groups and individuals who like us want to see real change.

We need as many people to donate as possible. Even €1 will send a message to the establishment that you have had enough. It is as much about the numbers of donations we receive as the amount.

We ask everyone from Donegal to Cork from Galway to Dublin and all in between to help us by donating anything you can to give Enda Kenny a message he will never forget.

This is the only chance for people outside of Mayo to let Enda Kenny know he is not fit to hold office

It won't be easy, we know that, but we are going to fight as hard as we can to make sure Enda Kenny is not returned to government. 

Please support us in anyway you can. Share this on Facebook and Twitter if you cant afford to donate. Tell your friends, the ones who are here and the ones who have had to move away. 

Every Euro and Cent you donate will go towards leaflets, posters and press advertising as well as mail shots around the local communities throughout Mayo.
